input: DOCTOR: What brings you in today?\nPATIENT: Well, my son is 7, and he’s been really unsteady when he walks, and he keeps falling, especially lately. It’s gotten worse over the past couple of years, and he also screws up words sometimes when he talks. We’re worried because he’s been behind other kids and it just doesn’t seem right.
output:
THINKING: The patient reports that their 7-year-old son has worsening unsteadiness when walking, frequent falls, occasional speech issues (screwing up words), and developmental delay compared to other children his age. These details have been confirmed and are consistent with prior information. No new facts are introduced.

ANSWER: The patient is the parent of a 7-year-old boy who has been increasingly unsteady when walking and falling more frequently over the past couple of years. He sometimes screws up words when talking. The child has been behind other children in development, and his parents are worried that something may be wrong.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?
PATIENT: Well, my son is 7, and he’s been really unsteady when he walks, and he keeps falling, especially lately. It’s gotten worse over the past couple of years, and he also screws up words sometimes when he talks. We’re worried because he’s been behind other kids and it just doesn’t seem right.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about how your child's walking and talking have changed over time, and are there any other concerns or new behaviors you've noticed recently?
PATIENT: Well, he used to walk a little better when he was younger, but lately he keeps falling more and it's really hard for him to stand steady. His talking is not as clear as before, and he seems to get frustrated more easily. There are some days he just seems more tired or upset for no obvious reason.
output:
THINKING: The conversation reinforces that the child's unsteadiness and falls have worsened over time, and his speech clarity has declined, with increased frustration and tiredness noted. No new facts outside what was previously summarized are introduced.  
ANSWER: The patient is the parent of a 7-year-old boy who has been increasingly unsteady when walking and falling more frequently over the past couple of years. He sometimes screws up words when talking. The child has been behind other children in development, and his parents are worried that something may be wrong.

input:
DOCTOR: What brings you in today?

His talking is not as clear as before, and he seems to get frustrated more easily. There are some days he just seems more tired or upset for no obvious reason.
DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about how your child's movements and behavior have been affecting his daily activities, as well as any concerns you have noticed that haven't been covered yet?
PATIENT: Well, he’s really unsteady when he tries to walk, and he falls a lot, even just walking inside the house. He gets frustrated because he can’t do things like other kids, especially with school and playing. Sometimes he seems upset or tired, and I worry about what’s going to happen as he gets older. I guess I’m just worried about everything—if he’ll keep having these problems or if it’s going to get worse.
output:
THINKING: The latest conversation reinforces and expands on the child's current symptoms, including worsening unsteadiness, frequent falls even indoors, and speech difficulties. The parent also notes his increased frustration, tiredness, and emotional upset, as well as concerns about his developmental progress and future. No new clinical facts outside these confirmed details are introduced.  
ANSWER: The patient is the parent of a 7-year-old boy who has been increasingly unsteady when walking, falls more frequently, especially inside the house, and has had difficulty with speech clarity, sometimes screwing up words. His walking and talking difficulties have worsened over the past couple of years. The child is behind other children in development. He often appears tired or upset and becomes frustrated more easily. The parent is worried about his current problems, his developmental progress, and the possibility that his condition may worsen.
